fields.headline: In brief
fields.bodyText: Foot and mouth Stung by claims that the Lake District is "closed" due to the foot-and-mouth crisis, the National Park has issued an information pack listing local attractions, lane-based walks, village events and activities that can still be enjoyed in the area. The pack, Right Here, Right Now! is regularly updated and can be obtained from Cumbrian tourist information centres, or by sending an SAE to The Lake District Visitor Centre, Brockhole, Windermere, Cumbria LA23 1LJ. The English Tourism Council this week opened a visitor information hotline, open seven days a week from 10am-8pm, on 0870 2415659. The hotline will steer callers to regional tourist boards. Wales has launched a Tourism Charter aimed at reassuring visitors that much of the country is still open for business. The Charter contains a code of conduct for the tourism industry and practical advice for the visitor, as well as for those who live in Wales. An information helpline 08080 1000000 gives daily updated information about what's on and what's open in Wales. Information is also being updated daily on the Welsh Tourist Board website at www.visitwales.com. Scotland: For the latest information on what's open, call the Scottish Tourist Board on 0131-332 2433, or visit www.visitscotland.com Northern Ireland: Information hotline: 02890 524279/524590, visit: www.discovernorthernireland.com. Many tourist attractions, such as the Giant's Causeway, are owned by the National Trust and more visitor information is available on 0870 4584000, www.nationaltrust.org Republic of Ireland: For the latest advice and update on events and activitities, visit www. irelandtravel .co.uk, or the Irish Times site at www.ireland.com Isle of Man: Tourism chiefs are urging visitors to continue with their travel plans. The majority of the island's attractions are unaffected and plans are going ahead for the TT races in June, although the Manx National Rally (May 11-12) has been cancelled. For latest details, call: 01624 686801 Mapping it out Goldeneye Map-Guides can suggest hundreds of destinations for those wishing to travel in Britain. The Map-Guides detail descriptions with opening times and map references to many attractions, but people should still call ahead for the latest advisory during the foot-and-mouth crisis. Their cycling route series illustrates circular on-road routes. Map and guides £5, map & guidebook with cycling route series £6 available by calling 01242 575943, or by visiting www.goldeneyemaps.com
